prompt: I sold a duplex and have $105k in proceeds. Should I pay off my $103k house or my $20k truck to remove a co-signer?
main_answer: Sell the truck. You shouldn’t be driving a $40k truck making $45k a year. Use the money to pay off the house and be debt-free. Drive something cheaper.
extra_context: Caller is single, makes ~$45k, and got $105k from selling a duplex. Truck worth $40k, owes $20k. Wants to remove a co-signer from mortgage.

prompt: My wife and I make $350k but have $1M in debt, including a $1500/month lease on a Mercedes. Should we get out of it?
main_answer: Yes, get rid of the lease. You’re broke despite your income. Sell the car even if you owe money on it and buy a cheap used car. You need to overhaul your lifestyle and get on the same page financially.
extra_context: Caller and his wife have $1M in debt: $180k student loans, $70k credit cards, $690k mortgage, and $1500/month lease. Household income is $350k.

prompt: I'm a teacher with a $3800/month income and a $120k/year eBay side hustle. Should I quit my job to do eBay full time?
main_answer: Not yet. Build up at least 6–12 months of your salary in savings from the side hustle before quitting. That’s $24k–$48k. Once you have a cushion, make the jump.
extra_context: Teacher making $3800/month. Sells vintage clothes and collectibles on eBay, pays himself $4k/month. Considering quitting to go full time.

prompt: We have $42k in credit card debt and a company offered to consolidate it into a $500/month payment over 4 years. Should we do it?
main_answer: No, avoid consolidation schemes—they're often scams. Instead, list your debts smallest to largest and use the debt snowball method. Cut expenses, increase income, and stay focused.

prompt: I'm paying off my mom's $20k debt, but now my brother took over some of it. She keeps spending. Should I keep helping?

prompt: I'm 47, divorced, and trying to pay off $10,000 in credit card debt while living paycheck to paycheck. Should I pull $10,000 from my Roth IRA to pay off my credit cards?
main_answer: Please don't do that. If you take that money out of the Roth IRA, you're going to rob all of the future growth and you'll likely pay penalties. It also doesn't change the behavior that got you into the debt. Instead, sell your company stock, use some savings, and increase your income. Consider getting a roommate, pausing retirement contributions, and picking up extra work like Ubering. This needs to be your number one priority.
extra_context: She makes $2,200/month and just got bumped to 40 hours/week. She has $2,200 in savings, $1,500 in stock, and a $1,200 mortgage. Her car is paid off.

scoring_criteria.5: Do not touch the Roth IRA, instead pay down debt with extra work, use savings/stock, and cut expenses. Aligns fully with the show's advice.
scoring_criteria.4: Strongly advises against using the Roth IRA, but lacks the urgency or full scope of income-boosting measures.
scoring_criteria.3: Mentions not using the Roth IRA but lacks clear alternatives or omits key advice on behavior change and budgeting.
scoring_criteria.2: Suggests partial withdrawal from IRA or ambiguous alternatives.
scoring_criteria.1: Advocates for using the Roth IRA as the best or only option.
scoring_criteria.0: Encourages full Roth IRA withdrawal without any context or caution.

prompt: I'm newly engaged after 7 years together and want a big wedding, but I feel guilty since we plan to buy a house in two years. Should I still have the wedding I want?
main_answer: Yes, have a wedding. Tell your partner what you want, even if it feels embarrassing. Set a budget for the wedding and put anything beyond that toward the house. Choose guilt over resentment. It’s just a math problem—buying the house might be delayed six months, but that’s life.
extra_context: She wants to celebrate with family who live in another state, and has been frugal her whole life. She is feeling tension between desires and financial planning.

scoring_criteria.5: Encourages a modest wedding within a budget and postponing the house purchase slightly if needed. Emphasizes communication and compromise.
scoring_criteria.4: Supports the wedding but lacks financial planning details or doesn't mention budgeting explicitly.
scoring_criteria.3: Says the wedding is okay but doesn’t address the house tradeoff or emotional dynamics.
scoring_criteria.2: Suggests forgoing the wedding entirely to save for the house.
scoring_criteria.1: Dismisses her feelings and prioritizes the house with no compromise.
scoring_criteria.0: Recommends going into debt for a lavish wedding.

prompt: I’m worried I bought too much house a year ago and am considering selling. Should I sell now?
main_answer: No, nothing's on fire. Your mortgage is 31% of your take-home pay—not ideal, but manageable. You love the home and you're not in a crisis. Keep paying it down, and consider refinancing to a 15-year mortgage down the line. Stay put unless your financial situation drastically changes.
extra_context: she earns $95,000, has a fully funded 3-month emergency fund, and owes $256,000 on a $340,000 home now worth $435,000. She loves the house but wants to follow Ramsey steps correctly.

scoring_criteria.5: Recommends keeping the home, outlines no urgency to sell, suggests paying it down and eventually refinancing.
scoring_criteria.4: Generally advises staying but lacks clarity on income ratio or future planning.
scoring_criteria.3: Neutral stance with minimal justification either way.
scoring_criteria.2: Suggests selling without strong financial reason.
scoring_criteria.1: Recommends selling due to guilt or regret without assessing numbers.
scoring_criteria.0: Advises panic-selling with no context or evaluation.

prompt: My brother wants to sell his half of our co-owned property. I’d like to keep it as a rental but don’t have the cash to buy him out. Should I borrow $65,000 to buy his half?
main_answer: No, don’t borrow. You’re not in a position to invest in real estate while you still have a personal mortgage. Work on paying off your own home first and maybe work out a rental agreement with your brother for a few years until you can buy him out.
extra_context: He still owes $105,000 on his own home, has no other debt, and makes just under $70,000/year. He wants to invest for his kids' future.

scoring_criteria.5: Firmly advises against borrowing for real estate while still owing on personal mortgage, encourages paying off debt first.
scoring_criteria.4: Advises against borrowing but without strong emphasis on current obligations.
scoring_criteria.3: Warns vaguely but lacks concrete steps or alternatives.
scoring_criteria.2: Says borrowing is okay with disclaimers.
scoring_criteria.1: Encourages borrowing as the primary or only option.
scoring_criteria.0: Strongly promotes borrowing and disregards existing mortgage.

prompt: My dad took out a $60,000 Parent PLUS loan for my college and now says I’m responsible for it, even though I never agreed to that. Should I start paying it?
main_answer: No, it’s not your debt. You never agreed to repay it and it's solely in your father’s name. He’s rewriting history to offload his financial burden on you. You’re not responsible, and if it costs you the relationship, that's on him—not you.
extra_context: He is 28, a state trooper. He and his wife make $8,000/month and have already paid down some debt. His father blames his mother and refuses adult conversation about the loan.

scoring_criteria.5: Affirms Jordan is not responsible, supports clear boundaries and emotional detachment.
scoring_criteria.4: Says Jordan probably doesn’t owe the loan but leaves room for guilt.
scoring_criteria.3: Acknowledges Jordan's dilemma but suggests partial payment.
scoring_criteria.2: Encourages paying some of the loan to avoid conflict.
scoring_criteria.1: Tells him to take on the debt for peace in the family.
scoring_criteria.0: Insists he is legally and morally responsible for the loan.

prompt: I was gifted $3,000 by my grandparents for education or investment. I put it into ETFs years ago and now it’s grown to $4,500. Should I use it to pay down debt?
main_answer: If you follow through on your debt-free plan and then invest more going forward, yes—using it to become debt-free is consistent with the spirit of the gift. But don’t use it irresponsibly or it dishonors the intention.
extra_context: She has $40,000 in debt and is newly on Baby Step 2. His grandfather only stipulated that the money be used for education or investment, not spent frivolously.

scoring_criteria.5: Allows use for debt only if it’s part of a larger plan to invest and change behavior.
scoring_criteria.4: Supports paying debt but omits emphasis on follow-through.
scoring_criteria.3: Suggests paying debt without tying it back to investment goals.
scoring_criteria.2: Says use it now without regard to gift intent.
scoring_criteria.1: Encourages spending it on non-educational, non-investment items.
scoring_criteria.0: Suggests cashing out and blowing the money.

prompt: I’m 24, recently graduated, and could be debt-free next month if I cashed out my $3,000 IRA. Should I do it?
main_answer: No, don’t do it. You’ll lose money to taxes and penalties. Instead, go berserker for 60 days—pick up extra jobs like Uber and sell stuff to get that last $5,000 paid off. Sprint to the end.
extra_context: He has reduced his $60,000 in debt down to the last $5,000. He and his wife are tempted to cash out his old 401k rollover to finish faster.

scoring_criteria.5: Urges not touching retirement, encourages hard work and final push.

prompt: I’m recently divorced, selling my house, and work remotely. I’ll have over $300,000 cash—should I rent, live with family, or take a job as a sorority house director for free lodging?
main_answer: Don’t buy a home yet. Wait six months to a year. If the sorority house director role is an adventure and not about clinging to your daughter, do it. Otherwise, just rent a nice one-bedroom and take time to heal.
extra_context: She is 48, makes $105,000/year, will have $315,000 in cash and $250,000 in retirement savings after her divorce. Her daughter is in college near the sorority house.

scoring_criteria.5: Advises delay on home purchase, focuses on healing and independence, allows adventure if healthy.

prompt: I’m in med school and my wife is starting her master’s. We’ll have around $360,000 in student loans. Should we invest while in school?
main_answer: No. Stop all investing and don’t take on any more debt. Try to cash flow your remaining education. If needed, pause your career dreams to avoid this debt load. You can’t invest your way out of debt.
extra_context: John is 24, about to have $360,000 in med school debt. He and his wife will be earning $60,000 a year total while studying. They’re tempted to keep contributing to IRAs.

scoring_criteria.5: Urges stopping all investing, avoiding more loans, and focusing on cash flow.
scoring_criteria.4: Recommends no investing but leaves options open for continued borrowing.

scoring_criteria.2: Allows limited investing despite overwhelming debt.
scoring_criteria.1: Says investing while borrowing is okay for long-term gain.

prompt: My wife and I make $260,000 and have $120,000 left on our mortgage and a $17,000 car loan. We want a bigger house for our twins. Should we upgrade now or pay everything off first?
main_answer: Pay off everything first. Use savings to wipe out the car loan and the mortgage, then start saving aggressively for the new house. Rent out your current place if needed, but don’t carry debt into the next home purchase.
extra_context: Matt and his wife recently had twins. They own a $224,000 home, owe $120,000 on it, and have $260,000 in savings and income combined.

scoring_criteria.5: Clear advice to pay off all debt first before upgrading the home.

prompt: I'm considering changing jobs for a $27,000 raise but it would mean selling my house of one year and possibly living with my mother-in-law. Should I take the job?
main_answer: Yes. You'll make more money, move back to be near family, and you're not forced to live with your mother-in-law—you can rent. Sell the house after September 22 to avoid short-term capital gains tax. Pay off debt with the proceeds.
extra_context: I would move from Cleveland to West Virginia for a salaried position, increasing from $61k to $88k. I have a $155k mortgage on a $230k home. I also have $20k in debt including credit cards and medical bills.

scoring_criteria.5: Recommends taking the job, timing the sale for tax reasons, and avoiding unnecessary family arrangements.

prompt: I'm debt-free with $45,000 saved for a house. Should I invest this money or keep it in savings?
main_answer: Put the money in a high-yield savings account or CD. Don't invest money you're saving for a house unless the timeline is five years or more. Since you're actively house hunting and ready to jump on the right opportunity, keep it out of the market. It's not melting ice when you're getting ready to use the money soon. You're not doing the wrong thing by keeping house-buying money liquid.
extra_context: I'm debt-free with stable income but paying premium rent due to job requirements. I'm actively watching the housing market and learning my area.

scoring_criteria.5: Recommends high-yield savings account or CD for house fund, explains timeline principle (don't invest money needed within 5 years), affirms caller is making right choice
scoring_criteria.4: Recommends keeping money liquid for house purchase, mentions high-yield savings, good understanding of timeline but minor gaps in explanation
scoring_criteria.3: Basic understanding that house money should be kept safe, mentions savings account but lacks clarity on timeline principle
scoring_criteria.2: Weak advice about keeping money safe, partial understanding of the situation
scoring_criteria.1: Poor grasp of the situation, suggests risky investments or inappropriate advice
scoring_criteria.0: Completely wrong advice like investing house fund money or other off-topic suggestions

prompt: I'm a disabled veteran with $50,000 in savings and no IRAs. How should I invest this money?
main_answer: Find some kind of work you can do from home or self-employed work that you can control - hours, stress level, volume. This would give you earned income needed for Roth IRA contributions. Keep part of the $50,000 as your emergency fund and invest the rest. Without earned income, work with a SmartVestor Pro to invest in low-turnover mutual funds (good for taxable accounts). Consider coding, contract work, or other self-employed options designed around your needs.
extra_context: I have PTSD from military service, receive substantial disability payments, and have been struggling to transition to civilian work. The hosts emphasize dignity in work and finding something tailored to my specific needs.

scoring_criteria.5: Recommends finding suitable work-from-home income for Roth IRA eligibility, suggests SmartVestor Pro for low-turnover mutual funds, addresses both investing and income creation with sensitivity to PTSD
scoring_criteria.4: Good advice on creating income and investing, mentions key concepts but may miss some specifics about low-turnover funds or Roth IRA requirements
scoring_criteria.3: Basic understanding of need for income and investing, but lacks specific guidance on tax-efficient investing or IRA requirements
scoring_criteria.2: Weak advice that partially addresses investing but misses income creation importance or tax considerations
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding of the situation, inappropriate advice for someone with disability income
scoring_criteria.0: Completely wrong or insensitive advice that ignores the caller's PTSD or financial situation

prompt: I have $32,000 in debt and want to invest for retirement and buy a house. What should I prioritize?
main_answer: Follow the baby steps in order: 1) Keep your $1,200 starter emergency fund, 2) Cut up credit cards and attack the $7,000 credit card debt first, then student loans, 3) Build fully funded emergency fund of 3-6 months expenses, 4) Then invest 15% in retirement, 5) Then save for house down payment. Don't do smart things at the wrong time - buying a house while you have debt and no savings turns a smart thing into a dumb thing. Use Every Dollar budgeting app to track expenses.
extra_context: I'm a new graduate excited about multiple financial goals but need guidance on proper sequencing. The hosts emphasize not celebrating graduation by making financial mistakes and following the baby steps order.

scoring_criteria.5: Clearly explains baby steps order, emphasizes paying off debt first before investing or house buying, mentions cutting up credit cards, explains why order matters
scoring_criteria.4: Good understanding of debt payoff priority, mentions most key steps but may miss some details about emergency fund timing
scoring_criteria.3: Basic understanding that debt should be paid first, but lacks clarity on specific steps or reasoning
scoring_criteria.2: Weak advice that partially addresses debt payoff but suggests doing multiple things simultaneously
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding, suggests investing while carrying debt or other problematic advice
scoring_criteria.0: Completely wrong advice like taking on more debt for house or ignoring debt payoff

prompt: I'm 21 with $27,000 saved and want to buy a Mustang for $20-25,000. Is this smart?
main_answer: You're in range ratio-wise since you'd pay cash and stay debt-free, and total vehicles shouldn't exceed 50% of annual income. However, since you have a company car and this would be a weekend toy, consider waiting. The $20,000 represents most of your net worth. Consider delaying 1-2 years to see what other goals emerge (house, wedding, etc.). If you buy, choose carefully for resale value in case priorities change. Save up additional cash beyond your $14,000 emergency fund first.
extra_context: I'm making smart financial choices, graduating debt-free, with good income lined up. The hosts appreciate my responsible approach but suggest considering opportunity cost since it would be mostly a toy car.

scoring_criteria.5: Acknowledges the purchase is within acceptable ratios, but recommends waiting due to opportunity cost, suggests saving additional funds beyond emergency fund, emphasizes resale considerations
scoring_criteria.4: Good advice about ratios and waiting, mentions most key points but may miss some details about emergency fund protection
scoring_criteria.3: Basic understanding of vehicle purchase guidelines, suggests caution but lacks specific reasoning
scoring_criteria.2: Weak advice that either approves purchase without conditions or disapproves without good reasoning
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding of the situation or ratios involved
scoring_criteria.0: Completely wrong advice like financing the car or ignoring the caller's strong financial position

prompt: I'm almost debt-free but struggling to get motivated about saving $25,000 for an emergency fund. What should I do?
main_answer: You should be highly motivated because your life IS an emergency right now - you've been out on short-term disability three times recently. With your income level ($170,000 when both working, about $110,000 from husband), you can save $25,000 in 6-8 months, not a full year. You make $14,000 per month when both working. With no debt payments, you can knock this out quickly. Your frequent disability episodes prove you desperately need an emergency fund.
extra_context: My husband and I have good income but I've had recent history of income disruption due to disability. I'm struggling with motivation for the emergency fund despite clear need based on my situation.

scoring_criteria.5: Points out that caller's situation proves need for emergency fund, calculates realistic timeline based on income, emphasizes urgency given disability history
scoring_criteria.4: Recognizes need for emergency fund given disability situation, provides good timeline estimate but may miss some motivational aspects
scoring_criteria.3: Basic understanding that emergency fund is important, mentions disability as reason but lacks specific timeline or urgency
scoring_criteria.2: Weak advice that acknowledges need but doesn't connect to caller's specific situation effectively
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding of why emergency fund is crucial for someone with disability income issues
scoring_criteria.0: Completely misses the point about disability creating emergency fund need or gives inappropriate advice

prompt: I'm 28, completely debt-free including my house, with emergency fund and retirement set up. I'm bored with just saving and want to make money faster. What should I do?
main_answer: You're in danger of messing all this up. The fastest way to get rich is boring. Don't go screwing around with get-rich-quick schemes trying to be cool, or you'll lose all the progress you've made. Your smart broke friends will make fun of your tortoise plan, but they're the ones with nothing. Be boring, be steady like the tortoise - he won the race. Put your money in basic, predictable investments and work with a smart investor pro for accountability so you don't make bad decisions out of greed.
extra_context: I cleared out all my checking and savings accounts to become 100% debt-free including my house at age 28, which is extremely rare. I'm investing in two Roth accounts and doing 10% in my TSP (Thrift Savings Plan). I feel lost about where to invest next and find just saving money boring.

scoring_criteria.5: Emphasizes staying boring and steady with investments, warns against get-rich-quick schemes, recommends working with a smart investor pro, acknowledges the temptation to overcomplicate wealth building
scoring_criteria.4: Recommends boring/steady investing approach, warns against risky investments, may miss some details about working with professionals
scoring_criteria.3: Basic advice about steady investing, may not emphasize the dangers of getting fancy or the psychological aspects
scoring_criteria.2: Vague investment advice, doesn't address the specific danger of overcomplicating things at this stage
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding of the situation or suggests risky investment strategies
scoring_criteria.0: Completely wrong advice or encourages speculative investments

prompt: I have a project car I've owned for three years but haven't made progress on. I'm paying off debt and have new career goals. Should I sell it?
main_answer: Your priorities have changed. When you bought the car three years ago, you didn't have the educational and career goals you have now. The car has gone further down on your priority list, and you'd rather be working on your educational goals than spending time and effort on the car. Since your goals have changed and the car is no longer a priority, sell it. There's a project car on every corner.
extra_context: My 1986 Nissan 300ZX has gotten dinged up and depreciated because people have been driving it. I need to do a body rebuild on it. The time and effort required for the car project is competing with my new educational and career goals, and I'd rather focus on those instead.

scoring_criteria.5: Clearly identifies that priorities have changed, explains that goals evolved since buying the car, recommends selling because educational goals are now more important, mentions that project cars are available when priorities change
scoring_criteria.4: Recognizes changed priorities and recommends selling, but may not fully explain the reasoning about competing goals
scoring_criteria.3: Basic advice to sell the car, understands it's not a current priority but lacks depth in reasoning
scoring_criteria.2: Suggests selling but doesn't clearly connect it to changed priorities and goals
scoring_criteria.1: Unclear advice or doesn't understand the priority conflict
scoring_criteria.0: Wrong advice or encourages keeping the car despite changed priorities

prompt: I'm 27, make $80K driving trucks, and want to become a deca-millionaire. Should I switch careers or stick with real estate investing and single stocks?
main_answer: You can achieve your goal following the principles. You're already investing 15% and should have 3-5 million in retirement accounts plus a pension by retirement, which is great. You can do real estate investing once you have a paid-for house by saving cash - don't take on more debt. But more importantly, if you work 40 years in a job you don't like, even with $3 million it won't be worth it. You should consider doing something you love - maybe financial coaching since you already help people for free and love talking about money. Do both your trucking and build a side hustle, then lean into what you were put on this planet to do.
extra_context: My goal is $10 million. I work 10-12 hour days driving semi truck locally and am at the top of my industry salary-wise, currently in baby steps 4 and 6. I calculated I should have 3-5 million in retirement accounts plus a pension by retirement. I already help people with money for free because I love talking about it. I don't dislike trucking but it isn't my passion, and I'm unsure if I want to do it for 40 years.

scoring_criteria.5: Confirms the $10 million goal is achievable, explains the math on retirement investing, mentions real estate with cash only after house is paid off, strongly emphasizes finding work you love and building a side hustle, warns against working 40 years in a job you don't like
scoring_criteria.4: Addresses the wealth-building strategy and career change aspects, may miss some details about the emotional/purpose side
scoring_criteria.3: Basic advice about investing and career, doesn't fully connect the importance of purpose in work
scoring_criteria.2: Limited advice, may focus only on the money aspect without addressing career satisfaction
scoring_criteria.1: Poor understanding of either the financial or career aspects
scoring_criteria.0: Wrong advice about debt, investments, or career strategy

prompt: I make $350K, have $3M invested, and took a 30-year mortgage at 3.2% to invest the difference at 12-13% returns. Should I pay off my mortgage?
main_answer: Yes, you should write the check and pay off the house today. You've done really well and proven that you can build wealth while leveraging debt, but it always works until it doesn't. You're an exception to the rule with your crazy income and 30 years of discipline. You can out-earn any poor decisions with your $350K income. Every financial advisor will tell you to do a 30-year over a 15-year so you can give them more money to invest - they're biased. The borrower is slave to the lender, and being debt-free changes your value system, decision-making, and identity. There's a physical weight with debt.
extra_context: I'm 48 and started investing at 16 with $500, being disciplined for 30 years and maxing out my 401k for 25 years. My wife and I make $350K total - over $100K is a guaranteed pension for life from my first career (I'm already retired from it), and I make over $100K in my new job. I have a six-month emergency fund in cash in my safe at home, plus a car payment at 3% interest. I have 20 years left on my mortgage with only $900 principal and $1,000 property taxes in my payment. My financial planner recommended the 30-year mortgage strategy 10 years ago.

scoring_criteria.5: Recommends paying off the house, acknowledges his success but explains that leveraging debt 'works until it doesn't', mentions the bias of financial advisors, explains the philosophical reasons about borrower being slave to lender and the psychological benefits of being debt-free
scoring_criteria.4: Recommends paying off the house and acknowledges his success, may miss some of the deeper philosophical reasoning
scoring_criteria.3: Basic recommendation to pay off the house, doesn't fully address why despite his success with the current strategy
scoring_criteria.2: Unclear recommendation or doesn't understand the complexity of his successful situation
scoring_criteria.1: Poor advice that doesn't consider his unique circumstances
scoring_criteria.0: Wrong advice or encourages keeping the debt
